title: Preference for judge or panel
p1: You can have your case heard by:
hearingPanelBullet2: A judge with two non-legal members, known as a 'panel'.

whatIsAPanel.p1: Non-legal members are lay people appointed because of their particular experience in the workplace as either workers or managers. A panel will consist of a judge, a member with worker or union experience, and a member with management experience. Each has an equal say in the decision.
whatIsAPanel.p2: A judge will decide whether your case is heard by a judge or by a panel. When making this decision, the judge will consider whether the case involves the sort of legal or factual problem where the experience of the non-legal members may help the tribunal reach its decision.

presidentialGuidance.summary: Presidential Guidance explains the types of cases where this experience may help.
presidentialGuidance.link1: Practice Directions and Guidance for Employment Tribunals(England and Wales).
presidentialGuidance.link2: Directions and Guidance for Employment Tribunal(Scotland).

p2: You have an opportunity to say if you would like your case heard by a judge or a panel. The judge will then consider your preference.
p3: If you express a preference, you will be asked to give reasons.

hearingPanelPreference.question: How do you prefer to have your case heard? (Optional)
hearingPanelPreference.judge: I prefer my case to be heard by a judge
hearingPanelPreference.panel: I prefer my case to be heard by a panel including non-legal members

hearingPanelPreferenceReasonJudge.required: Give a reason for selecting judge

hearingPanelPreferenceReasonPanel.required: Give a reason for selecting panel
